description.text: AngularJS has quickly become my favourite front-end web app framework, so much so that I can't imagine ever creating another website without it. In fact, this website relies heavily on AngularJS. The crown-jewel of my AngularJS experience is found at https://npgcloud.com, a web app where high profile customers such as Hudson Bay Company, 7-Eleven and Sprint go to design and print their name badges.

AngularJS is snel een van mijn favoriete front-end web app frameworks geworden, zo snel dat ik me zelf niet kan voorstellen of ik er zonder nog een site zal maken. Deze site gebruikt nogal wat AngularJS. Mijn AngularJS ervaring heeft een hoogtepunt bereikt met https://npgcloud.com, een web app waar welbekende bedrijven zoals Hudson Bay Company, 7-Eleven en Sprint gaan om hun badges te ontwerpen en te printen

I discovered Node and started learning its possibilities in June 2015. The simplicity to set up a running server with Node is quite frankly astonishing and the ease of adding community written plugins still amazes me on a daily basis. Currently I have 4 node apps running, 2 externally facing that have helped me automate various processes, including an app that made it possible to download software prevously only available via CD.
I've used a lot of plugins so far, the most notable ones would be:
  • Tedious To make SQL connections easy
  • Sequelize To make SQL queries using JS syntax
  • Mongoose To make query MongoDB
  • IIS Node To run node apps in IIS
  • Nodemailer Simple SMTP package to make mailing easy
  • Gulp To make development a breeze
There is always new stuff to learn in relation to Node and I am eager to keep learning it.

SQL Server is one of the environments I'm most comfortable in. I have been able to use SQL server to automate a plethora of processes saving countless hours of manual work and weeding out errors made by it: automating emailed orders, calling APIs to auto-process orders, getting form data from wordpress, adding tarriffed item counts to UPS labels, calculating US customs dues, sending packing slips to third party warehouses, auto-enrolling supply chain customers,.... I've received a substantial CEO award in 2015 for building a report that allowed users to correlate any 2 attributes of sales to show trending. I've set up a couple of SQL databases from scratch to use for various reasons: APIs, SSRS reporting cubes, Automated order processing and am savvy in creating all aspects of a new database (keys, procedures, functions, relationships, backups, jobs,...)

I first found Sequelize in the beginning of 2017 as I was searching for a tool to make SQL querying easier and making SQL injection hard. I stumbled upon Sequelize and have since implemented it in practically all my node apps. Since I'm know my way around SQL and I'm very accustomed to javascript syntax, this tool just married both into a fantastic tool to speed up all coding related to SQL.
